par.text: Caesium is a silvery-white, soft and ductile metal. The surface of a fresh cut is highly lustrous, but the lustre is instantly dulled in air. It is the most reactive lithium group element and has to be stored in kerosene. It reacts explosively with water and ignites spontaneously in air. Caesium causes severe burns and its salts are highly poisonous. It was discovered in 1860 by the German chemists Robert Bunsen and Robert Kirchhoff. The name of the element is derived from the Latin
meaning greyish-blue (two characteristic blue lines of its spectrum).
